BILL NUMBER:S1259

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the civil rights law, in relation to electronic monitoring

PURPOSE OR GENERAL IDEA OF BILL:
To require employers engaged in monitoring or intercepting electronic
communications of any employee by any electronic device or system to
provide notice of such monitoring.

SUMMARY OF SPECIFIC PROVISIONS:
This bill amends the civil rights law by adding a new section 52{a}.

Subdivision 1 defines for the purposes of the section the term
"employer", which shall not include the state or any political
subdivision of the state.

Subdivision 2 requires private employers engaging in electronic
monitoring, which includes monitoring or otherwise intercepting
telephone conversations or transmissions, electronic mail or
transmission, or internet usage of or by the employee, by any
electronic device or system, to give prior notice to employees in
writing, in an electronic record, or in another electronic form. The
notice must be acknowledged by the employee either in writing or
electronically. Employers are also required to post the notice in a
noticeable place which is readily accessible to employees.

In addition, employees shall be advised that any and all telephone
conversations or transmissions, electronic mail or transmissions, or
internet access or usage of by an employee by any electronic device
or system may be subject to monitoring at any and all times and by
any lawful means.

Subdivision 3 authorizes the attorney general to enforce the
provisions of the section. Any employer in violation of this section
shall be subject to a maximum civil penalty of five hundred dollars
for the first offense, one thousand dollars for the second offense
and three thousand dollars for the third and each subsequent offense.

Subdivision 4 does not apply to processes undertaken by employers to
manage the type or volume of incoming or outgoing electronic mail or
telephone voice mail or internet usage for the purpose of computer
system maintenance and/or protection.

JUSTIFICATION:
A report from American Management Agency's 2007 surveillance survey
determined employers fired employees for internet misuse based upon
cited violation of company policy and excessive personal use. In
addition, a Harris poll determined forty percent of five-hundred plus
employees to be unaware of their employers' monitoring policy.

Employers also have the availability of computer software that can
screen and store an employee's computer terminal and bard disk,
monitor internet usage such as web-surfing and electronic mail, and
monitor idle time or away time from an employee's computer terminal
without employee recognition. All these measures presume an employee
is at a disadvantage in recognizing and understanding an employers'
monitoring policy.

By requiring employer notification of monitoring or intercepting of
information at any and all times through lawful means ensures
employee privacy and an understanding of consequences resulting from
inappropriate internet activity. Requiring prior written notice of
electronic monitoring benefits employers as employees will be less
likely to undermine company standards. Further, companies will retain
the right to monitor computer usage, simply with the stipulation that
employees are informed of surveillance practices. This knowledge will
increase transparency within the organization and help to avoid
lawsuits and litigation regarding invasion of privacy.

PRIOR LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
2009-2010: S.4755 - Passed Codes. Advanced to 3rd Reading Calendar.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None. The bill only apply to those employers who have prior electronic
monitoring practices.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
Shall take effect on the one hundred eightieth day after it becomes law.
